captions.text:
So there's science, and then
there's science fiction,

and then there's
just outright hoaxes.

And with December 21, 2012,
coming up, it seems like

we're just going to have
to tell you outright, right now
what is not going to happen!
[INTRO]

December 21, 2012,
as you may have heard,

from some people's perspective,
is pretty much D-day for Earth.

You're probably familiar with
the Mayan apocalypse scenario,

which I covered in a different
episode of this show.

You can go watch it right now.
It's quite interesting.

Which basically is saying:
the world is going to end because

the Mayan long calendar is reaching
this somewhat roundish number.

That's basically
all that's happening.
It happens every 400 years or so.

And every time it's happened before,
nothing impressive has happened.

That was your end-of-
the-world hoax primer.

Now we can truly let
the debunking begin.

Myth: Nibiru, the rogue planet
that was discovered by the Sumerians

let's not get into how they
discovered it while we can't see it.

It's nearing the end of its
3,600-year orbit and it's going to
come around and smash into the Earth.
When?! Oh, December 2012, of course.

Of course NASA knows about this,
but they're covering it up.

Of course everyone with
a telescope of any size

can see this planet by now,
but they're covering it up.

It's a massive planet and it's
coming to get us in a year's time,

but you know, you might
as well keep it to yourself,

there's no reason
to induce mass hysteria.
We're all just going to die anyway.

Fact: Sumerians...
great at a lot of things,

like creating agriculture,
civilization as we know it,

writing down things,
that was super awesome,
not particularly great at astronomy.
For example they were not aware

of the concept of
planets orbiting stars.

Right, and also there
is no planet Nibiru.

If you go to any of the
websites that are advocating

this disaster scenario, they all
look like they were designed in 1996.

The date of Nibiru's
arrival keeps changing.

It was supposed to get
here early in 2003,
just not very good at math.

Myth: We're just going
to combine two here.

One: The earth is headed for
the equator of the galaxy,

and also the sun is going to be
pointing directly at the center

of the galaxy and this is going
to create a gravitational vortex

and everything will wobble
out of sync and flip over

and shoot off to the side
and drop down and the whole...

pancake the earth.
We'll all be dead.

Fact: I don't know where
to begin with this one!

So the galactic equator,
I think what they probably mean

is the "galactic plane,"
which is like, midway through
the thickness of the galaxy.

now that doesn't have any special
significance except that

it's kind of a cool
idea for it to have.

Also, we're like dozens of light
years away from being aligned

with the galactic plane, and we're
currently hurtling away from it,

as part of our 64 million-year
cycle of wobbling around
within the galactic plane.

As far as the sun lining up
with center of the galaxy,

I mean, that's sort of
a cool idea to think,

"Ah the sun is lining up with
the center of the galaxy!"
It doesn't mean anything.

This episode is giving
me David Tennant hair.

Final myth: On december 21, 2012
the earth's magnetic sphere

is going to turn inside out,
and it's going to tear our planet

apart or possibly we'll just be
killed by lethal doses of radiation.

Fact: Actually,
this happens sometimes.

So, you're allowed to
freak out a little bit.

It's really interesting actually
that the Earth's magnetic sphere
occasionally turns inside out.

And that doesn't mean that
south becomes north
and north becomes south.

Actually, let's put a graphic
of that up. It's weird.

It goes from being a normal looking
magnetic sphere to being like,
"What the frick is that!?"

The last of these reversals
was about 780,000 years ago.

though the time between the
reversals varies wildly.

And it's estimated to take
between 1,000 and 10,000 years

for the reversal to
actually take place.

But yeah, this happens
and if it had happened
during the age of exploration,

people's compass needles started
pointing the wrong way

that would have been
really weird, but it didn't.

If it does start to happen
though, if our magnetic field

starts to weaken and
flip, that could have

some potential consequences
for our lifestyles,

we'd probably have to use more
sunscreen, but there's nothing

in the fossil record that indicates
that these hundreds of flips

that our magnetic field
has gone through

over the course of history has
resulted in anything like the kinds

of mass extinctions that we see for
like, the dinosaurs for example.

I'm getting my blood pressure
all worked up over this.

But let's just give a shout
out to David Morrison, who has

the thankless job of responding
to these weirdos at NASA.

He's just such an
earnest and patient guy,

and he's constantly
responding to the questions

of freaked out
teenagers and adults alike.

And I'm just going to give
him the final word for this video.

DAVID: There is no threat to
Earth in 2012. There is no danger.

All of the talk about
a doomsday is a big hoax

perpetuated on the internet and
with people trying to make money.
So please, don't worry about it.

HANK: I hope you're
less freaked out now.

In the comments please go ahead and
respond to the crazy people
who are telling me why I'm stupid.

I really appreciate your help in
dealing with those people

because I can't respond to them
all, but you can respond to us

on Facebook and Twitter, give us
suggestions for what we should

talk about in the future and ask
any questions that you have

and we'll do our best to answer.
Thank you for watching SciShow.

comments.author: Incidental Penguin

comments.text:
I actually have an acquaintance, who made a considerable amount of money, 
because of the 2012 thing. Although most people didn't fall for it, he did 
find a few people, CONVINCED the world or civilization was going to end. He 
offered to buy their houses for what amounted to 20c on the dollar! The 
former home owner gets to take a trip around the world - before the world 
comes to an end and everyone dies - and he gets a $300,000 house for only 
$50-60K. He bought 7 houses this way!

I'm not saying he's any pillar of morality, but - after reselling most of 
those houses, at market value - he is now very wealthy. It also goes to 
show how stupid and gullible some people can be. ﻿

comments.text:
Whats most interesting about the  'boy who cried wolf'  phenomenon is that 
natural selection never disposed of it. Its actually a good thing  for the 
welfare of the herd/tribe to have the occasional false alarm, since it 
keeps us on our toes. I think it was Sapolsky who observed that if a baboon 
child uses the alarm call ( leopard alert! )  the rest of the band does not 
look to the child but to its mother.. so, tell your next apocalypse 
doomcrier that his momma shoulda whupped him more- but keep an eye out for 
leopards anyway. Just in case.﻿

comments.text:
Look I understand that but most Christians aren't like that and you know 
it. There are extremist like there are in every affiliation in the world, 
so if you want to argue against those people LET'S GO! I'm ready when you

that has carried them through their life and that is their interpretation 
of the world then leave them be. We have our views, let them have theirs.
comments.author: Sam Jogia

comments.text:
+Sam Jogia
Apparently your definition of hurtful and mine are two different things. I 
think it's hurtful when people encourage others to "put a biblical spin on 
it". It's hurtful when people choose to ignore facts so they can keep their 
faith. It's hurtful when people deny children proper medical care because 
their beliefs say "god will handle it".

All of these things are hurtful, and if it makes me a dick to say "it is 
NOT ok to believe this crap", then so be it. I will continue to say it 
because it needs to be said. If you don't like it, tough shit.
comments.author: Gunner3789

comments.text:
+Gunner3789 Dude go ahead and say what you want but just because you want 
to prove your point doesn't mean that you have to be a dick. NOW if they 
were being a dick go ahead and tell them like it is but the person wasn't 
saying anything hurtful to anyone.
comments.author: Sam Jogia

comments.text:
+Sam Jogia Since when has it been said that I have to respect someone 
else's beliefs? I have to respect someone's RIGHT to hold those beliefs, I 
cannot tell them they can't believe in something, but I CAN point out how 
utterly retarded those beliefs are. If you want to believe in the magic 
flying water bottle on the moon that watches over us all, so be it, but 
understand that it is also MY RIGHT to tell you how stupid you look.

comments.text:
A light year is basicly the way the light had taken after traveling one 
year. Given the fact that a light second is 299 792,458 km   a light year 
is  : 9.460.730.472.580,8 km .  For a little scale the average space 
between earth and the sun (keep in mind that the orbit is elliptical so 
this changes over the course of a year dramatical) is around 500 light 
seconds. And the our next Galatic stellar Neighbor Alpha Centauri is 
around  4,34 light years away.

comments.text:
The current is called gravity, so to speak. It's a force, that brings 
objects together, sometimes flinging things away. No literal 'current' 
could really exist in the 3 dimensional universe in the way you're implying.
comments.author: Kirsten M.

comments.text: what the actual fuck?
comments.author: Nicholas Cardenas

comments.text:
nope, gravity is controlled by mass, basically, objects of higher mass pull 
objects of lower mass towards them, orbiting bodies are always being 
pulled, and if they weren't moving forward, they would fall towards the 
object

comments.text:
+Jief Yang Sadly that's the flaw with our system. When people vote 
(democrats or republicans) they vote radically for the most part. 
Democratic leaders are almost socialist, and Republican leaders are almost 
anarchist (with a few exceptions of course). And because of that some of 
(not even most of) the people who represent and lead the country are 
absolutely nuts. It's just the people who are nuts get all the press, 
because it's more entertaining. I love my country and the people in it even 
if I don't always agree with some of the things it does. I won't say it's 
the greatest, but it's pretty good, and I'm glad I live here.
